{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3584200,"name":"","username":"manso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T19:49:20.533Z","cooked":"

Our original auto-align to reef command was based off of this CD Thread:

From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef Programming
seen some struggle for teams to auto align to the reef so I wanted to create a tutorial of how to do it. before I begin a I will point out a few things: I will show the simplest way to auto align to the reef this is not the most optimized way to do it but it works really good when tuned well defiantly faster than 99% of drivers. also I will talk about the vision processor side a bit but will focus more on the robot code side. ok first of all to start you will need a way to 3d track april ta…

However, this caused weird odometry issues during auto, and caused event triggers to not work properly.

So I had our programmer come up with their own solution. This is their code so far:

Pastebin

auto align command help - Pastebin.com

Pastebin.com is the number one paste tool since 2002. Pastebin is a website where you can store text online for a set period of time.

Our programmer is confused between all of the different get-bot-pose functions and he has no clue what they really do, or when to use each method.

LimeLightHelpers javadocs

limelightlib-wpijava-reference.limelightvision.io

LimelightHelpers

declaration: package: frc.robot, class: LimelightHelpers

Pastebin.com","clicks":7},{"url":"https://limelightlib-wpijava-reference.limelightvision.io/frc/robot/LimelightHelpers.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"LimelightHelpers","clicks":3},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/from-zero-to-auto-align-to-reef-tutorial-how-to-simply-auto-align-to-the-reef/494478","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6593 Alumni/Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-difference-between-all-of-the-get-bot-pose-functions-in-limelighthelpers/498473/1","custom_user_title":"6593 Alumni/Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3584218,"name":"","username":"ninjadrknss","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninjadrknss/{size}/247388_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T20:03:57.285Z","cooked":"

For one, just looking at the docs reveals a variety of return types. For simplicity, I recommend sticking to the Pose Estimate option, as it integrates nicely with existing odometry and Kalman filters.

Secondly, there is the frame of reference for how the pose system is originated. FIRST/wpilib has been moving towards using the blue pose system exclusively, so wpiBlue is the better option.

Lastly, there is the difference in the solve method. MegaTag1 does not use the robot yaw value and is more robust to errors in offset measurements. However, MegaTag2 can offer greater accuracy but requires the robot yaw.

If I were to offer a suggestion, I would use the getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue(String limelightName) option. *you still should make sure the configure the limelight position and angle.

One suggestion for you code is to use a more robust odometry setup for the closed loop drive. If you were to lose sight of the april tag, it would return null or a pose at (0, 0), both of those cases are currently unaccounted for in your code atm.

As I think you are using CTRE swerve, it has a built in odometry setup all ready, so it should not be too difficult to get that working.

Looking at your isFinished condition, I would also suggest debouncing your booleans, as you don’t want weird pose jitters to cause your command to end too early.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-04-08T20:12:31.949Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":34.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":498473,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-difference-between-all-of-the-get-bot-pose-functions-in-limelighthelpers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57180,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"751"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-difference-between-all-of-the-get-bot-pose-functions-in-limelighthelpers/498473/3","custom_user_title":"751","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3584227,"name":"","username":"TheBatman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thebatman/{size}/255139_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T20:09:42.325Z","cooked":"

I agree with @ninjadrknss, but i will also advice you to use a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator, you can have a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator object in your swerve subsystem class, and in the periodic have the following code:

LimelightHelpers.PoseEstimate poseEstimate = LimelightHelpers.getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue(cameraName);

mPoseEstimator.addVisionMeasurement(poseEstimate.pose, poseEstimate.timestampSeconds);
mPoseEstimator.update(getRobotRotation(), getModulePositions());

And than you can access the pose estimate using mPoseEstimator.getEstimatedPosition()
It might take a bit more time to set-up rather than just using LimelightHelpers.getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue(cameraName); but i think it will make a significant difference.

The advantage of the original LL pose (LimelightHelpers.getTargetPose3d_RobotSpace("") I think) was all 12 reef sides are treated the same and you don’t have to know the exact position in the field space. The disadvantage is it relies on the bad assumption as pointed out in other posts that the AprilTag is always present and the odometry isn’t used in between AprilTag appearances.

I’d do what others suggest and use the addVisionMeasurement to use AprilTags to more or less extent depending on distance to the tag and when very close to the tag (but still in sight) resetOdometry to the tag pose.

I suggest using the WPILib PIDController as originally coded and I’d consider adding rotController.enableContinuousInput as appropriate for your gyro.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

The disadvantage is it relies on the bad assumption as pointed out in other posts that the AprilTag is always present and the odometry isn’t used in between AprilTag appearances.

I think this was causing our wierd odometry issues during autos. So I’ve updated the code to update the odometry during execute()

Pastebin

drive to pose command help 2 - Pastebin.com

Pastebin.com is the number one paste tool since 2002. Pastebin is a website where you can store text online for a set period of time.
